newsitem.title: FRANCE: French train strike eases but Sunday traffic hit.
newsitem.headline: French train strike eases but Sunday traffic hit.

text.p: A strike by French train conductors was set to disrupt rail traffic for a fifth day on Sunday, prolonging travellers' misery over a long holiday weekend despite a decision by some strikers to go back to work.
State railway company SNCF said one in three trains were cancelled on its main lines on Saturday and most inter-city routes would be similarly disrupted on Sunday.
High-speed Eurostar trains to London through the Channel Tunnel were unaffected but the strike did hit a third of traffic on the Thalys express service linking Paris and Brussels.
By Monday, however, the SNCF expected to be running a near normal service and urged all of its conductors to resume work.
"There is no reason to keep up the strike because we have made a considerable effort, without precedent, for the conductors," SNCF chairman Louis Gallois told French television.
Despite talk of a breakthrough on Friday, the strike dragged into the Pentecost weekend after most conductors voted to reject concessions won by unions in negotiations with the SNCF.
Traffic jams built up on some motorways on Saturday as extra holidaymakers took to the roads for the three-day break.
Conductors on Saturday called off their action at one Paris mainline station, Montparnasse, as well as a number of provincial terminals including Rennes and Marseille.
But others extended the strike at the capital's Gare de Lyon and the cities of Montpellier and Bordeaux in southern France.

The SNCF has agreed to promote an extra 860 of the current 10,000 conductors and hire 200 more this year as well as raise their monthly bonus to 900 francs ($155) from 700 francs ($120) by year-end and to 1,000 francs ($170) early next year.
But, in a rift between unions, the hardline Sud-Rail, kept out of talks because it represents a minority of staff, said on Saturday the concessions fell far short of its demands.
"Instead of indulging in propaganda, the management must negotiate," it said in a statement urging a longer strike.
The Socialist-backed CFDT union, France's largest, said it had won significant concesssions and urged its members to examine the whole package on offer when voting their next move.
The SNCF apologised to its travellers and said the strike would badly hurt the company.
The conductors staged a similar strike last month in another sign of opposition to austerity policies of the centre-right government of Prime Minister Alain Juppe.
